prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCO+ for CO Peak 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is to observe CCH, HCN, HCO+, and HNC toward CO Peak 1.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The velocity resolution is assumed to be 0.95 km/s, which can resolve a typical line width of 5 km/s in the LMC clouds.

We aim at resolving structures of molecular clouds in the LMC with a molecular-cloud-core size, and explore their chemical compositions. For this purpose, we need the angular resolution of 1.2", which corresponds to the linear resolution of 0.3 pc at the distance of the LMC.

The intensity of the weakest line (the strongest hyperfine component of CCH) is 0.02 K with Mopra (beamsize ~40"). If the source has a size of 5" (~1.2 pc), the brightness temperature is 1.3 K. This corresponds to 12.2 mJy/beam at a resolution of 1.2". With the RMS of 1.2 mJy (velocity resolution ~2.7 km/s), the line of the third strongest hyperfine component of CCH will be detected with 5 sigma significance. Although we request the resolution of 0.95 km/s, we will combine several successive channels to improve the S/N ratio for detection. If the line is enough strong, we can study the velocity structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: HCO+ for N44C
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is to observe CCH, HCN, HCO+, and HNC toward N44C.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The velocity resolution is assumed to be 0.95 km/s, which can resolve a typical line width of 5 km/s in the LMC clouds.

We aim at resolving structures of molecular clouds in the LMC with a molecular-cloud-core size, and explore their chemical compositions. For this purpose, we need the angular resolution of 1.2", which corresponds to the linear resolution of 0.3 pc at the distance of the LMC.

The intensity of the weakest line (the strongest hyperfine component of CCH) is 0.05 K with Mopra (beamsize ~40"). If the source has a size of 5" (~1.2 pc), the brightness temperature is 3.2 K. This corresponds to 29.9 mJy/beam at a resolution of 1.2". With the RMS of 3 mJy (velocity resolution ~2.7 km/s), the line of the third strongest hyperfine component of CCH will be detected with 5 sigma significance. Although we request the resolution of 0.95 km/s, we will combine several successive channels to improve the S/N ratio for detection. If the line is enough strong, we can study the velocity structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CS & 13CO for CO Peak 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is to observe CS, SO, CH3OH, C18O, and 13CO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The velocity resolution is assumed to be 0.86 km/s, which can resolve a typical line width of 5 km/s in the LMC clouds.

We aim at resolving structures of molecular clouds in the LMC with a molecular-cloud-core size, and explore their chemical compositions. For this purpose, we need the angular resolution of 1.2", which corresponds to the linear resolution of 0.3 pc at the distance of the LMC.

The intensity of the SO line is 0.06 K with Mopra (beamsize ~40"). If the source has a size of 5" (~1.2 pc), the brightness temperature is 3.8 K. This corresponds to 42.9 mJy/beam at a resolution of 1.2". CH3OH, which is not detected with Mopra, is expected to weaker than SO by a factor of 10. With the RMS of 1.5 mJy (velocity resolution ~2.5 km/s), we can detect the CH3OH line with 3 sigma significance. Although we request the resolution of 0.86 km/s, we will combine several successive channels to improve the S/N ratio for detection. If the line is enough strong, we can study the velocity structure. We also observe C18O and 13CO as standard molecules to trace the molecular gas along the line of sight. The 13CO line is enough bright, while the C18O line may be faint. Non detection of C18O does not matter, because it can provide the upper limit of the optical depth of the 13CO line.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CS & 13CO for N44C
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: This SG is to observe CS, SO, CH3OH, C18O, and 13CO toward N44C.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The velecity resolution is assumed to be 0.86 km/s, which can resolve a typical line width of 5 km/s in the LMC clouds.

We aim at resolving structures of molecular clouds in the LMC with a molecular-cloud-core size, and explore their chemical compositions. For this purpose, we need the angular resolution of 1.2", which corresponds to the linear resolution of 0.3 pc at the distance of the LMC.

The intensity of the SO line is 0.1 K with Mopra (beamsize ~40"). If the source has a size of 5" (~1.2 pc), the brightness temperature is 6.4 K. This corresponds to 72.2 mJy/beam at a resolution of 1.2". CH3OH, which is not detected with Mopra, is expected to be weaker than SO by a factor of 10. With the RMS of 2.4 mJy (velocity resolution ~2.5km/s), we can detect the CH3OH line with 3 sigma significance. Although we request the resolution of 0.86 km/s, we will combine several successive channels to improve the S/N ratio for detection. If the line is enough strong, we can study the velocity structure. We also observe C18O and 13CO as standard molecules to trace the molecular gas along the line of sight. The 13CO line is enough bright, while the C18O line may be faint. Non detection of C18O does not matter, because it can provide the upper limit of the optical depth of the 13CO line.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) is the nearest external galaxy, whose metallicity is known to be lower by factor 2 than in our Galaxy. In our previous study, we observed 7 molecular clouds in the LMC with the Mopra 22 m telescope and found the characteristic chemical composition specific to the LMC. To explore its origin, we here propose the observation of 2 clouds in the LMC, which are in different evolutionary stages. We resolve individual cores in each cloud, and characterize their chemical compositions. According to our Mopra observations, CCH is found to be abundant in the clouds of the LMC than that of our Galaxy, while CH3OH is less abundant in the LMC. Considering the low-metallicity of the LMC, this is interpreted as the effect of extended photodissociation regions (PDRs) due to the lower abundance of dust grains. In addition, abundances of sulfur-bearing molecules, CS and SO, slightly differ from cloud to cloud, probably reflecting the evolutional stages of each cloud. We examine these characteristic features in the LMC at high angular resolution.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, The University of Tokyo
